question.content:
consider the table MORTYS_MIND_BLOWERS [morty_id, event, colour, description]

For those who dont watch the show a mind blower is a little memory stored in a tube. Morty re-watches the memories. The memories come from rick who removes them from mortys brain whenever morty's mind has been 'blown'

 

Which query would select the morty_id's who have been proposed to by mr poopy butthole and have beaten rick in checkers.

explanation.content:
A: only checks for one of the two events

B: checks if the event is equal to two different things at the same time

C: would be correct but selects mortys who have been proposed to and havent beaten rick in checkers

D is correct. First it checks if the morty_id is one in which that has been proposed to by mr poopy butthole. It then checks the event of the current tuple its checking. If this is beat rick in checkers it will select the id. Therefore that morty has had both events.

A.content:
SELECT morty_id FROM MORTYS_MIND_BLOWERS

WHERE event = 'proposed to by mr poopy butthole'

B.content:
SELECT DISTINCT morty_id FROM MORTYS_MIND_BLOWERS 

WHERE event = 'proposed to by mr poopy butthole' AND event = 'beat rick in checkers'

C.content:
SELECT DISTINCT morty_id FROM MORTYS_MIND_BLOWERS

WHERE morty_id IN 

    (SELECT morty_id FROM MORTYS_MIND_BLOWERS

    WHERE event = 'proposed to by mr poopy butthole')

AND morty_id NOT IN

    (SELECT morty_id FROM MORTYS_MIND_BLOWERS
    WHERE event = 'beat rick in checkers')

D.content:
SELECT DISTINCT morty_id FROM MORTYS_MIND_BLOWERS
WHERE morty_id IN
    (SELECT morty_id FROM MORTYS_MIND_BLOWERS
    WHERE event = 'proposed to by mr poopy butthole')

AND event = 'beat rick in checkers'

question.content:
AFL Finals are here!!!
The AFL board has decided that it is time for them to review their database for the AFL Finals Series. They have enlisted you to help them.

They have given you the following relational schema.

 

AFL

 

And set of functional dependencies.

 

FD1:    PlayerID → {Name, Position, Club}
FD2:    GameID → {HomeTeam, AwayTeam, Date, Result}
FD3:    VenueID → {VenueName, Address}
FD4:    HomeTeam → {VenueID, Club}
FD5:    AwayTeam → Club
FD6:    {PlayerID, GameID} → Statistics

 

(Note: this uses the assumption that there is only one team per club and a home team has a set and unique venue)

 

Find the highest normal form of this relation and decompose this relation to achieve BCNF.

explanation.content:
The highest normal form is 1NF because the key is being partially used in functional dependencies (failing 2NF).

In this case to decompose to BCNF, it is enough to simply put the functional dependencies into separate tables.

A.content:
1NF

 

R0

 

R1

 

R2

B.content:
2NF

 

R0

 

R1

 

R2

 

R3

 

R4

C.content:
1NF

 

R0

 

R1

 

R2

 

R3

 

R4

 

R5

D.content:
2NF

 

R0

 

R1

 

R2

 

R3

 

R4

 

R5

question.content: How would you map the ternary relationship below, taking note of the cardinality?

explanation.content:
Answer D is the answer for mapping a ternary relation of the given cardinality.

 

Answer A would be correct if the ternary relationship had a cardinality of Many to Many to Many. However, when the relationship has cardinality of 1 to Many to Many, the entity with cardinality one does not need to be part of the primary key in the new relation, however, it does need to be added to the relation.

 

See Module 5 slide 32 -33

A.content:
• Create a new relation between the entities participating in the ternary relation i.e. (E1, E2, E3) -> R[]
  • Add the a primary keys of all entities to the new relation. i.e. R[A,C,G]
  • The combination of primary keys from entities become the primary key for the new relation  R[A,C,G]
  • Reference the newly added attributes as foreign keys to the original entity i.e. R.A references E1.A, R.C references E2.C, R.G references E3.G
  • Add any simple attributes from the ternary relationship into the new relation i.e. R[A,C,G,H ]

B.content:
• Add the primary keys from the entities with a cardinality of many, to the entity with cardinality 1 i.e. E3[G, F, E, A, C]
  • Reference the newly added attributes as foreign keys from the entities they came from E3.A references E1.A, E3.C references E2.C
  • Add any simple attributes from the ternary relation to the entity with cardinality 1 E3[G, F, E, A, C, H]

C.content:
• Create a new relation between the entities participating in the ternary relation i.e. (E1, E2, E3) -> R[]
  • Add the a primary keys of entities with cardinality of many to the new relation. i.e. R[A,C]
  • The combination of primary keys from entities become the primary key for the new relation R[A,C]
  • Reference the newly added attributes as foreign keys to the original entity i.e. R.A references E1.A, R.C references E2.C
  • Add any simple attributes from the ternary relationship into the new relation i.e. R[A,C,H ]

D.content:
• Create a new relation between the entities participating in the ternary relation i.e. (E1, E2, E3) -> R[]
  • Add the a primary keys of all entities with to the new relation. i.e. R[A,C,G]
  • Reference the newly added attributes as foreign keys to the original entity i.e. R.A references E1.A, R.C references E2.C, R.G references E3.G
  • The combination of primary keys from entities with a cardinality of Many become the primary key for the new relation (E1, E2 are many to many-> R[A,C,G]
  • Add any simple attributes from the ternary relationship into the new relation i.e. R[A,C,G,H ]

question.content:
A set of attributes that can uniquely identify any tuple in the relationship.

 

What question best suits the above definition?

explanation.content: A set of attributes that uniquely identifies any tuple is called a super key. Candidate and primary key are not the best solution because they are considered the minimal amount of attributes to identify any tuple which was not specified in the description.

C.content: What is a primary key?

D.content: What is a functional dependency?

question.content: During the mapping process from an ER diagram to a relational schema, what are the components that strictly require making a new relation in the schema?

explanation.content:
There are 8 steps during the mapping process (see Module 5 slides):

1. Entity Mapping
2. Weak Entity Mapping
3. Binary 1:1 Relationship Mapping
4. Binary 1:N Relationship Mapping
5. Binary M:N Relationship Mapping
6. Multi-valued Attribute Mapping
7. N-ary Relationship Mapping
8. Super & Sub-classes Mapping

 

One easy way to remember what to do during each step is:

All components in the ER diagram, except for Binary 1:N and 1:1 Relationships, require a new relation during the mapping process.

 

However, for sub-classes, creating a new relation is not strictly required. This depends on the relationship between the superclass and its sub-classes (overlapping or disjoint, total or partial participation). In many cases, the sub-classes' attributes can be merged into the relation of the superclass for reducing redundancy.

C.content:
Entity
Weak Entity
Binary M:N Relationship
Multi-valued Attribute
N-ary Relationship

D.content:
Entity
Weak Entity
Binary M:N Relationship
Composite Attribute
N-ary Relationship

question.content: Mos Eisley Cantina is setting up an online reservation system to manage reservations for the establishments renowned VIP lounge. During signup, a user must enter a username which is unique, first name, last name, home world, occupation and email address which is also unique.   Which of the following statements correctly identifies the keys in the table?

explanation.content:
B - Correct

A superkey is any set of attributes which can uniquely identify a tuple. It is possible for a superkey to contain extra attributes which on their own are not unique. If a superkey includes all attributes it can be referred to more specifically as a trivial superkey.   It is possible to have more than one superkey.

 

A candidate key contains the minimum set of attributes which uniquely identify a tuple. Candidate keys differ from superkeys in that they must not include any attributes which do not contribute to uniquely identifying a tuple. A candidate key is a subset of superkeys and also called a minimal superkey. It is possible to have more than one candidate key.

 

The primary key is chosen from one of the identified candidate keys. In the given example this could be either {username} or {email} which one is chosen is a design decision. While a primary key can be composed of more than one attribute there can only be one primary key.

 

Generally speaking, the candidate key whose values are expected to not change is chosen as the primary key although this does not need to be the case.

 

Also refer to: 
Ref:
Chapter 5 of R.Elmasri and S.B.Navathe, Fundamentals of Database Systems 7th Global Edition. Page 188 - Section 5.3.2
Chapter 14 of R.Elmasri and S.B.Navathe, Fundamentals of Database Systems 7th Global Edition. Page 506 - Section 14.3.3

A - NOT CORRECT:
The candidate key {username, firstname} includes the attribute "firstname".
"firstname" is not required to uniquely identify a tuple, thus disqualifying this attribute set from being a valid candidate key. Candidate keys must be minimal keys, meaning they must only contain the minimum required attributes necessary to uniquely identify a tuple. 

C - NOT CORRECT
The chosen primary key {firstname, lastname, occupation} does not uniquely identify a tuple.

 

D - NOT CORRECT

The super key {homeworld, email, firstname , lastname, occupation} does not uniquely identify a tuple.

A.content:
Super Keys:
{username, firstname , lastname, occupation}
{username, email, firstname , lastname, occupation}

 

Candidate Keys:
{email}
{username, firstname}

 

Primary Key:
{username}

B.content:
Super Keys:

{username, firstname , lastname, occupation}

{username, email, firstname , lastname, occupation}

Candidate Keys:
{email}
{username}

 Primary Key:

{username}

C.content:
Super Keys:
{username, firstname , lastname, occupation}
{username, email, firstname , lastname, occupation}


Candidate Keys:
{email}
{username}


Primary Key:
{firstname, lastname, occupation}

D.content:
Super Keys:
{username, firstname , lastname, occupation}
{homeworld, email, firstname , lastname, occupation}


Candidate Keys:
{email,username}


Primary Key:
{username}

question.content:
Consider the Following Chess Players and Tournaments:

 

The player's name in 'PLAYER' must contain both their first and last name. Additionally, ratings below 2000 are not accepted.

 

Suppose the Table 'WINNER' is supposed to record the player who wins a given tournament in a given year.

WINNER [ Player ID,Tournament Name, Year, Prize Money]

 

Select the insertion/s below which do not violate any integrity restraints.

explanation.content:
A: Both first and last name of player must be given: Domain Constraint.

B: The player ID 15 is already occupied by 'Magnus Carlsen': Key Constraint.

C: Player ID in winner is not valid: Referential Constraint.

E: Player ID in PLAYER must be given since it is a key: Entity Constraint.

A.content:
PLAYER <10, Anand, 2000, Indian, 37>

TOURNAMENT <UQ chess comp, Gatton>

WINNER<15, Australian Open, 1999, $10>

B.content:
PLAYER <15, Anand Viswanathan, 2754, Indian, 37>
TOURNAMENT <UQ chess comp, Gatton>
WINNER<19, Fischer Memorial, 2001, $6>

C.content:
PLAYER <16, Anand Viswanathan, 2754, Indian, 37>
TOURNAMENT <UQ chess comp, Gatton>
WINNER<18, Fischer Memorial, 2016, $900>

D.content:
PLAYER <16, Anand Viswanathan, 2754, Indian, 37>
TOURNAMENT <INFS1200 Chess Trial, Great Court>
WINNER<22, Fischer Memorial, 2016, $900>

question.content:
A relation R has multiple functional dependencies in the form X --> A. For the relation schema R to be in 3NF (Third Normal Form), it is required that for each of these functional dependencies:

 

(note assume that the relation R has already passed the 1NF test)

explanation.content:
To be in 3NF form the relation schema R needs to be:

In 1NF - This is given at the start of the question

In 2NF - This is true if it is in 1NF and every non-prime attribute is fully functionally dependent on every key

In 3NF - This is true if it is in 2NF and no non-prime attribute is transitively dependent on every key

 

To satisfy both the 2NF and 3NF rules we can check that for every functional dependency X --> A of R, either X is a superkey of R or A is a prime attribute of R.

 

Reference slide 63 of module 6

A.content: both X needs to be a candidate key of R and A to be a prime attribute of R

B.content: both X needs to be a prime attribute of R and A to be a superkey of R

C.content: either X needs to be a primary key of R or A to be a superkey of R

D.content: either X needs to be a superkey of R or A to be a prime attribute of R

question.content:
The council of ricks wanted to create a database which tracked the locations each rick was travelling to with his portal gun. The database tracks which morty the rick had at the time of use so they could determine which adventures were the most successfull and thus choose which mortys to get for themselves. However, when it came to mapping the rest of the relational schema the citadel's security was comprimised and thus they could not finish. The first half of the relational schema is as below.

 

RICK [BAC, rickID, age, homeDimension]

PORTALGUN[Dimension, universe, co-ordinates, portalGunID]

 

A morty is defined by a unique ID number and has a number of attributes. Assuming a morty can exist without being attached to a rick, and each adventure is a ternary relationship which also stores if it was a success(1) or failure (0) in the outcome attribute. Which two tables correctly finishes the relational schema?

explanation.content:
The answer is a mapped ternary relationship between Morty, rick and the portal gun.

The key trick in this question is reading the answer carefully.

A: is incorrect because MORTY is not uniquely identified.

B: is correct

C: is incorrect as the UoD stated that the relationship also has an outcome attribute to determine if the adventure was a success

D: is not uniquely identified by an ID as stated in the UoD

A.content:
MORTY[mortyID, statusWithJessica, age]

ADVENTURE[rickID, portalGunID, mortyID, outcome]

B.content:
MORTY[mortyID, statusWithJessica, age]

ADVENTURE[rickID, portalGunID, mortyID, outcome]

C.content:
MORTY[mortyID, statusWithJessica, age]

ADVENTURE[rickID, portalGunID, mortyID]

D.content:
MORTY[mortyID, statusWithJessica, age]

ADVENTURE[rickID, portalGunID, mortyID]

question.content:
How to decompose the following relation to achieve BCNF:

 

PURCHASE (CustomerID, CustomerName, Address, PostCode, State, ItemID, ItemName, Price, Quantity, Date)

 

FD = {

  • CustomerID   ->   CustomerName, Address, PostCode, State
  • ItemID   ->   ItemName, Price
  • CustomerID, ItemID   ->  Date, Quantity
  • PostCode   ->   State

}

explanation.content:
Candidate Keys: (CustomerID, ItemID)

 

Partial Dependencies (2NF violated)

  • CustomerID -> CustomerName, Address, PostCode, State
  • ItemID -> ItemName, Price

Decompose to achive 2NF:

CUSTOMER (CustomerID, CustomerName, Address, PostCode, State)
ITEM (ItemID, ItemName, Price, Quantity)
ORDER (ItemID, CustomerID, Date)

 

 

Transitive Dependencies (3NF violated)

  • PostCode -> State

Decompose to achive 3NF:
CUSTOMER (CustomerID, CustomerName, Address, PostCode)
STATE (PostCode, State)
ITEM (ItemID, ItemName, Price)
ORDER (ItemID, CustomerID, Quantity, Date)

 

These relations already satisfied BCNF

A.content:
CUSTOMER (CustomerID, CustomerName, Address, PostCode, State)
ITEM (ItemID, ItemName, Price)
ORDER (ItemID, CustomerID, Quantity, Date)

B.content:
CUSTOMER (CustomerID, CustomerName, Address, PostCode, State)
ITEM (ItemID, ItemName, Price, Quantity)
ORDER (ItemID, CustomerID, Date)

C.content:
CUSTOMER (CustomerID, CustomerName, Address, PostCode)
STATE (PostCode, State)
ITEM (ItemID, ItemName, Price)
ORDER (ItemID, CustomerID, Quantity, Date)

D.content:
CUSTOMER (CustomerID, CustomerName, PostCode)
STATE (PostCode, State, Address)
ITEM (ItemID, ItemName, Price)
ORDER (ItemID, CustomerID, Quantity, Date)

question.content:
Consider the DFD attempting to model Tutorial 1 Question 2.

"A customer requests details on his/her savings and/or cheque account(s) from a bank. The
identification is first checked. The appropriate savings and/or cheque account information
is retrieved and provided to the customer."

Is there a problem with the DFD?

explanation.content:
The DFD is correctly modelling the system described. 

A) More than one data flow noun phrase can appear on a single arrow as long as all of the flows on the same arrow move together as one package. [1]

B) While the customer both request and receives data the customer is not a direct part of the information system and thus shown to be outside of the system.
C) Correct answer.
D) It is valid for a process to have multiple outputs of data. 


Ref: [1] Chapter 7 of Hoffer, George and Valacich, Modern Systems Analysis and Design 4th Edition. Page 206 - Table 7-4

A.content: The DFD is incorrect because the customer is sending different data within the same data flow.

B.content: The DFD is incorrect because the customer is outside of the system.

C.content: The DFD is correctly modelling the described system.

D.content: The DFD is incorrect because process 2.0 has more outputs than inputs.

question.content:
There is a relation R[A,B,C,D] with the following functional dependencies:
A ---> BC
A ---> D
B ---> C

 

Is relation R in 3NF? if not explain why.

 

Note: Assume R has passed the test for 1NF

explanation.content:
Option A - R is not in 3NF as there is a transitive dependency issue

Option B - Correct! A is the primary key that determines B,C,D. However C is dependent on B which is a transitive dependency so therefore R is not in 3NF.

Option C - The primary key is unique as seen from the functional dependencies (A determines B,C,D)

Option D - There is no limit to functional dependencies for a relation

Option E - R is in 2NF as there are no attributes that are determined by part of the candidate key.

B.content: No, R is not in 3NF due to a transitive dependency.

C.content: No, R is not in 3NF as the primary key is not unique

D.content: No, R is not in 3NF as there are too many functional dependencies

question.content: Given an ER Diagram, with an existing 1 - N (One to many) relationship, which of the following is true when converting to a table format?

explanation.content: When given a One to many relationship, and converting from an ER diagram to a relational mapping, the entity on the "n" side of the relationship has its table extended with the primary key from the "one" side; see tutorial 4 sheet for example of this (Question 1 or 2)

A.content: A new table is created for the relationship

B.content: The existing table for the "n side" entity is extended with the attributes of the "one side" entity

C.content: The existing table for the "n side" entity is extended with the primary key of the "one side" entity

D.content: The existing table for the "one side" entity is extended with the primary key of the "n side" entity

question.content:
No spoilers.

Arya stark has made a simple database to track who she has taken off her lift and how she did it. (just because).

Her relational schema is as follows

 

VICTIM[name, family, list_number]

KILL[name, weapon, location]

WEAPON[weapon, type]

Assuming name, family, weapon, location and type are all Varchars (not null) and list_number is an int.

 

If Arya was to insert some tuples into the database which set is valid?

Additionally think about which constraints are violated.

As well obviously there are loop holes in this schema such as multiple of the same list_number but for simplicity it is as is.

explanation.content:
A: is correct up until it references an undefined weapon. This violates the referential constraint

B: Violates the entity constraint as no value is entered for the location of the kill.

C: is Correct

D: is incorrect as there are two victims with the same key. This violates the key constraint.

C.content:
VICTIM <"Little Finger", "Baelish", 7>

VICTIM <"The Mountain", "Clegane", 6>

WEAPON<"zīrtys perzys", "dagger">

KILL<"The Mountain", "zīrtys perzys", "Kings Landing">

D.content:
VICTIM <"Little Finger", "Baelish", 7>

VICTIM <"Little Finger", "Clegane", 6>

WEAPON<"Needle", "sword">

KILL<"Little Finger", "needle", "Winterfell">

question.content:
Find the candidate key(s) for the following relation.
R [A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H]
A---->D
C, F ----> G
G ---->B, H

E ----> A

explanation.content: A and D can be realised by E, also B, G, and H are connected to C, F.

C.content: A, E

D.content: C, E, F

question.content: Convert this E/R diagram to relations, resolving the dual use of "name" in some reasonable way. Which schema below is the most reasonable translation from ER to relations? (foreign key attributes are shown in bold)

explanation.content: As a weak entity, the key of Cities should include both the key of the owner entity (pname) as well as the partial key of the weak entity (cname). Pname is also a weak entity here.

A.content: Cities [name, mayor], Provinces [name, premier]

B.content: Cities [cname, pname, mayor], Provinces [pname, premier]

C.content: Cities [cname, pname, mayor], Provinces [pname, premier]

D.content: Cities [cname, pname, mayor], In [cname, pname], Provinces [name, premier]

question.content:
Two Chess players (One player playing with the white pieces (WP) and another playing with the black pieces (BP)) play a game of chess. The result is recorded and their ratings are then recalculated based on the result.

 

Given the Relation R(WP PlayerID, WPname, WPage, WPrating, BP PlayerID, BPname, BPage, BPrating, Result, BPnewrating, WPnewrating) and the set of FDs below

{WP Player ID ---> {name, age, rating}
BP Player ID ---> {name, age, rating}
{WP Player ID, BP Player ID} ---> {Result, WPnewrating, BPnewrating}
Result ---> {WPnewrating, BPnewrating}}

 

What is the Candidate Key/s for R and what is the highest form of normalization that has been satisfied in R0 - R3 above?

explanation.content:
The only possible candidate key is WP Player ID and BP Player ID. 

This is in 2NF as WP Player new rating and BP Player new rating are functionally dependent on Result.

A.content:
Candidate Key is Result.

This is in 1NF.

B.content:
Candidate Key is Result and WP Player ID.
This is in 2NF.

C.content:
Candidate Key is WP Player ID and BP Player ID.
This is in 2NF.

D.content:
Candidate Key is WP Player ID and BP Player ID.
This is in BCNF.

question.content: In what situation should you use VARCHAR as the type when adding a new column?

explanation.content:
VARCHAR is used for columns with character entries of varying lengths. It's useful because if, say, you set the max length to 100 characters and only 60 characters are entered, CHAR would keep the missing 40 characters as blank spaces. This wastes space. VARCHAR will only record what is entered. This will result in a smaller database with the same amount of information.

 

You could use TEXT, but VARCHAR stores the data within the table (whereas TEXT is stored off the table with a pointer leading it to the table) and so is faster if the input is of a reasonable length.

C.content: When the column is for text of a set length

D.content: When the column is for text of varying lengths

question.content:
To investigate fair pay in the Mushroom Kingdom the following database was created.

Note: Character(ONAME) refers to Occupation(ONAME).

 

Which constraints (if any) are violated when the following is inserted into the database?

Insert < 'Mount', 'Apples', 4 > into the OCCUPATION table.

explanation.content:
Option A - Entity integrity is not violated as the key (ONAME) of the new insert is not null.

Option B - Key integrity is not violated as the key (ONAME) of the new insert is unique.

Option C - Referential integrity is not violated as the ONAME attribute in the OCCUPATION table does not reference any other table. Although CHARACTER table references ONAME, this does not cause a referential integrity error as there is no attribute referencing null.

Option D - Domain integrity is not violated as the attributes of the new insert are following the format implied in the database.

Option E - Correct. There are no violations with this insert.

C.content: Violates referential integrity

D.content: Violates domain integrity

question.content:
Fill in the following blanks with the most appropriate answer combination:

 

A common form of a (i)________ model is a data flow diagram.

A data flow diagram is a graphical tool that allows (ii)________ (and users)

to depict the (iii)________ of data in an information system.

explanation.content: Adapted from readings posted in Module 2 - Requirements Engineering

C.content:
(i) process

(ii) designers
(iii) positioning

D.content:
(i) process

(ii) analysts

(iii) flow

question.content:
consider the table RICKS_ADVENTURE [rick_id, morty_id, location, did_jerry_come, is_beth_real]

 

Which query would select rick_id's which have gone on an adventure with morty c137 at least once.

Avoid multiple returns of the same value.

explanation.content:
A: checks if rick_id = 'c137' not morty's

B:correct

C: possibility of multiple rick_id returns. Tried to word it in the question that the query should select distinct rick_id's but sorry if it was vague.

D: This statement needs a group by

A.content:
SELECT rick_id FROM RICKS_ADVENTURE
WHERE rick_id = 'c137' AND is_beth_real = 'i doubt we will ever know'

C.content:
SELECT rick_id FROM RICKS_ADVENTURE
WHERE morty_id = 'c137'

D.content:
SELECT rick_id FROM RICKS_ADVENTURE

WHERE count(*) > 1

question.content:
Jerry ⊆ Rick

{Jerry, Bethany} ---> Morty

 

Using which two rules of inference are we able to infer that:

{Rick, Bethany} ---> Morty

explanation.content:
Jerry ⊆ Rick

 

Reflexivity implies: Rick ---> Jerry

 

 

Rick ---> Jerry

{Jerry, Bethany} ---> Morty

 

Pseudo-Transitive Rule implies: {Rick, Bethany} ---> Morty

C.content:
Reflexivity Rule

Union/Additive Rule

D.content:
Transitivity Rule

Pseudo-Transitive Rule

question.content: In a Context level DFD ( Data Flow Diagram), how many processes should be shown?

explanation.content: A Context Level DFD should only have 1 process as it shows the relationship between the entire system and external entities. This is also called a Level 0 DFD.

question.content: Which of the following is NOT one of the type of data models?

explanation.content:
A: Relational Data Model : Most commonly used in traditional applications

B: Legacy Data Model: Network and Hierarchical Data models

C: Object Data Model: Respond to applications with complex data and concept of object oriented in software engineering 

D: No such Data Model

C.content: Object Data Model

D.content: Database Data Model

question.content:
There are many different types of Pokemon. Each Pokemon can have more than one type, for example Gyrados is both Flying and Water type. 

How would you classify the sub-classes (types) of Pokemon?

explanation.content: If an entity (Pokemon) can participate in more than one of the sub-classes (types), they are overlapping.

question.content:
Consider the Relationship R (A,B,C,D,E,F,G,H,I)

and the set of FDs:

 

A → {B, C, D}

E → {F, G, H}

D → E

G → H

I → {A, D}

 

Which of the following pairs of statements is true?

explanation.content: I is the only possible candidate key. All elements in R are atomic and its non-prime attributes are functionally dependent on the whole of the candidate key (I).

A.content:
The Relationship R is in 1NF.

Both E and I are Candidate Keys.

B.content:
The Relationship R is in 2NF.

A is the only Candidate Key.

C.content:
The Relationship R is in 3NF.
I is the only Candidate Key.

D.content:
The Relationship R is in 2NF.
I is the only Candidate Key.

question.content:
Given the following relation and functional dependencies:

 

VEHICLE (RegNo, SSN, ChassisNo, EngineNo, Make, Model, Badge, Color, Seats, CTP_Contract)

 

FD1: RegNo → SSN, ChassisNo, EngineNo, Make, Model, Badge, Color, Seats, CTP_Contract

FD2: CTP_Contract → SSN

 

Assumed that several cars may have the same CTP_Contract (for example, two cars of the same person) 

 

Is this relation in 3NF and why?

explanation.content:
A: False - CTP_Contract → SSN is not a Partial Dependency

B: True - CTP_Contract is not a Super Key and SSN is not a Prime Attribute

C: False - SSN is not a Prime Attribute because it is not a subset of any candidate key

D: False - CTP_Contract is not a Super Key because several cars may have the same CTP_Contract

C.content:
YES

 

CTP_Contract is not a Super Key

but SSN is a Prime Attribute

D.content:
YES

 

SSN is a not Prime Attribute

but CTP_Contract is a Super Key

question.content:
A student is given the following Universe of Discourse from which they have to create a DFD. The first thing they do is underline some words:

 

Gooble is a large tech company. They have multiple web applications and products with millions of users. After some recent news, their image and reputation has become damaged. They would like to get feedback from many users and consumers in order to improve their image. Consumers who would like to provide feedback will need to fill out an online survey. To do this, they login to their Gooble account using their email address and password. They must then fill out a survey and can then add additional comments if they wish. The results of the survey are looked over by moderators to weed out any spam or bots and then the collected results are sent to the Gooble Marketing Team. The Marketing Team refines the results and, if neccessary, can reach out to individual consumers for further feedback.


What is the student doing?

explanation.content:
The student is identifying the potential external entities. External entities either provide or receive data (they are either the source or the sink of information).

Gooble, the consumers, the moderators and the Marketing Team are all potential external entities.

 

Identifying potential external entities is the first step when constructing a Data Flow Diagram from a Universe of Discourse.

C.content: Identifying the important instances of data flow.

D.content: Identifying the where the data is stored.

question.content: What is this relationship?

explanation.content: An Identifying Relationship is a relationship between a weak entity and its 'owner' entity.

C.content: Normal Relationship

D.content: Recursive Relationship

question.content: The ER model below outlines the basics of the Star Wars universe. Note the relationship "was" between Sith and Jedi which shows which Sith was previously a Jedi and turned evil. Sith (or Sith Lords) are enemies of the Jedi, and as Yoda once said: "Always two there are, a master and an apprentice" (meaning that over the course of history there are very few Sith Lords compared to Jedi). Given this information, on which entity would you put the foreign key when you are mapping the 1:1 relationship "was" and why?

explanation.content:
A is incorrect because, although true, a great number of nulls would be created for the Jedi who had not turned evil.

B is incorrect because because the number of attributes is irrelevant

C is partially correct since ordinarily a lack of total participation does give you a choice of which entity to put the foreign key in

E is incorrect because you do have to create a foreign key when mapping 1:1 relationships

 

D is the most correct answer because since there are so few Sith Lords (as outlined in the question) the number of nulls which would occur is minimized for those Sith who had not previously been Jedi. For example, if there were 100 Jedi and 10 Sith Lords with only 5 of them having previously been Jedi then if the foreign key was added into Jedi there would be 95 NULL values. If the foreign key is added to Sith, there would only be 5 NULL values.

A.content:
Jedi.

Because you would be able to show every Jedi who has now become a Sith in the Jedi table

C.content:
Either.

Because there is no total participation on either side of the relationship, it is perfectly fine to put the foreign key on either of them

D.content:
Sith.

Because there are fewer Sith than Jedi, the number of nulls accumulated over the lifetime of the database for Sith who were never a Jedi would be minimised

question.content: Suppose we have to create a table called UQStudents, which of these attributes should be the primary key?

explanation.content:
The answer is 'StudentID' because each student must have a unique ID number, which matches the requirement of a Primary Key.

Many students can have the same name as well as the same DOB so these are not the right answers.

Many students can share their Phone number and Email (siblings). Moreover, many may not have a phone number or an email, so these attributes can be null-valued, which cannot be used in primary keys.

C.content: StudentDOB

D.content: StudentPhoneNumber

question.content:
Consider the above table Livability(Country, HDI, GDP, CO2 emissions)

 

Which of the following tuples will feature in the result of the selection below?

SELECT * 

FROM Livability

WHERE           (HDI > 0.805 and GDP < 69,000)

                 or    (GDP > 20,000 and CO2 emissions < 8.932)

explanation.content:
A: Russia, Bolivia and Norway all fail to meet the standards in the WHERE.

B: Argentina fits the WHERE, though not of its attributes are listed. (they should be given the SELECT *).

C: Russia fails to meet the standards in the WHERE.

D: Correct.

E: Not all attributes listed and Norway does not fit the requirements.

question.content:
Relation R has eight attributes ABCDEFGH. Fields of R contain only atomic values. F = {CH -> G, A -> BC, B -> CFH, E -> A, F -> EG} is a set of functional dependencies (FDs) so that F+ is exactly the set of FDs that hold for R.

 

How many candidate keys does the relation R have?

explanation.content:
A+ is ABCEFGH which is all attributes except D.

B+ is also ABCEFGH which is all attributes except D.

E+ is also ABCEFGH which is all attributes except D.

F+ is also ABCEFGH which is all attributes except D.

So there are total 4 candidate keys AD, BD, ED and FD

question.content:
BookStore

Store(Store_id, Location, Phone, Super_Emp_id)

Employee(Emp_id, Store_id, Fname, Lname, Mobile, Salary,)

Stock(Store_id, Book_id, Qty)

Book(Book_id, Title, Author, Publisher_id)

Publisher(Publisher_id, Pub_name, Pub_address)

Customer(Loyalty_id, Dob, Name)

Transaction(Loyalty_id, Store_id, Date_Time, Book_id, Emp_id,)

 

 

All attribute with the same name refers to each other. And Store.Super_Emp_id references Employee.Emp_id

 

Find ALL Loyalty_id of Customer(s) who bought at least ALL the book(s) bought by the customer with Loyalty_id 'INFS1200'.

 

Assume only one book can be purchased per customer at a time.

explanation.content: This is a Double Negation question, you will need to use two NOT EXISTS in your sub query, and remember the select statement after NOT EXISTS is followed by SELECT * at all time. In our first select statement, we need to identify what we would like to display as the result of the query. And in our first sub query, we need to find all records of transaction of Loyalty_id = "INFS1200". Then we will need to link all the tables in our second sub query. Think about the linking process this way, what are we trying to find in the first two select statement. In the first one we are looking for Loyalty_id, so we will need to tell our database that the two Loyalty_id we are comparing are identical, secondary think about what we are after in our second query, we are after the Book_id purchased by "INFS1200", so we will need also link the Book_id in the second query to in the third query.

A.content:
SELECT DISTINCT X.Loyalty_id
FROM Transaction X
WHERE NOT EXISTS
(SELECT Loyalty_id
FROM Transaction Y
WHERE Y.Loyalty_id = "INFS1200"
AND NOT EXISTS
(SELECT *
FROM Transaction Z
WHERE Z.Loyalty_id = X.Loyalty_id
AND Z.Book_id = Y.Book_id));

B.content:
SELECT DISTINCT X.Loyalty_id
FROM Transaction X
WHERE EXISTS
(SELECT *
FROM Transaction Y
WHERE Y.Loyalty_id = "INFS1200"
AND NOT EXISTS
(SELECT *
FROM Transaction Z
WHERE Z.Loyalty_id = X.Loyalty_id
AND Z.Book_id = Y.Book_id));

C.content:
SELECT DISTINCT X.Loyalty_id
FROM Transaction X
WHERE NOT EXISTS
(SELECT *
FROM Transaction Y
WHERE Y.Loyalty_id = "INFS1200"
AND EXISTS
(SELECT *
FROM Transaction Z
WHERE Z.Loyalty_id = X.Loyalty_id
AND Z.Book_id = Y.Book_id));

D.content:
SELECT DISTINCT X.Loyalty_id
FROM Transaction X
WHERE NOT EXISTS
(SELECT *
FROM Transaction Y
WHERE Y.Loyalty_id = "INFS1200"
AND NOT EXISTS
(SELECT *
FROM Transaction Z
WHERE Z.Loyalty_id = X.Loyalty_id
AND Z.Book_id = Y.Book_id));

question.content:
What is the result of following SQL Queries

 

SELECT COUNT(*) FROM SCORE

SELECT COUNT(GPA) FROM SCORE

SELECT AVG(GPA) FROM SCORE WHERE SID='1001'

explanation.content:
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM SCORE

return 4

COUNT all records of table SCORE


SELECT COUNT(GPA) FROM SCORE 

return 3 because CSSE1001 GPA of Student 1001 is NULL

COUNT functions on specific nullable column does not include records which have NULL value in that column

 

SELECT AVG(GPA) FROM SCORE WHERE SID='1001' 

return 6 = (7+5)/2

AVG functions on specific nullable column does not include records which have NULL value in that column

question.content:
Compute the closure of the following relational schema:

 

Consider the below relational schema with the set RICK of FDs:

 

RICK = {OrderID → {Share, Date , Company, OrderQuantity, Address, Cost},
              Company→ {Name, Aim, Address},
              Cost→ {Buy-Price, OrderQuantity}}

 

Compute the closure and select the correct computation below.

explanation.content: A and C are missing a number of elements from the closure of OrderID. A is also missing some from Company and Cost. D has 'Quantity' in OrderID. This does not exist in the relational schema.

A.content:
{OrderID}+ = {Share, Date , Company, OrderQuantity, Address, Cost}

{Company}+ = {Name, Aim, Address}

{Cost}+ = {Buy-Price, OrderQuantity}

B.content:
{OrderID}+= {Buy-Price, OrderID, Share, Date , Company, OrderQuantity, Address, Cost, Name, Aim}

{Company}+ = {Company, Name, Aim, Address}
{Cost}+ = {Cost, Buy-Price, OrderQuantity}

C.content:
{OrderID}+ = {Share, Date , Company, OrderQuantity, Address, Cost}
{Company}+ = {Company, Name, Aim, Address}
{Cost}+ = {Cost, Buy-Price, OrderQuantity}

D.content:
{OrderID}+ = {OrderID, Share, Date, Quantity, Company, OrderQuantity, Address, Cost,    Name, Aim, Buy-Price}
{Company}+ = {Company, Name, Aim, Address}
{Cost}+ = {Cost, Buy-Price, OrderQuantity}

question.content: When representing attributes in an Entity Relationship Model, what is the right notation for multi-valued attributes?

explanation.content: Multi-valued attributes are set between curly brackets "{  }", while composite attributes are set between parenthesis "(  )". ChecK slide 20 of module 3.

question.content: In ER to relational mapping, what is the correct procedure for mapping binary M:N relationships?

explanation.content:
When mapping an M:N binary relation, a new relation is created that includes:

  • The primary keys of the participating entity types, referenced as a foreign key in the new relation
  • The combination of these foreign keys will be the primary key of the new relation
  • Include any simple attributes of the M:N relation as attributes of the new relation

This information is from Module 5, slide number 23

A.content:
• Pick the entity with the most attributes in the relationship
  • Add its primary key to the other participating entity as an attribute
  • Reference it as a foreign key to the original entity
  • Add any attributes on the M:N relationship to the chosen entity

B.content:
• Create a new relation
  • Add a primary key made from the combination of primary keys from the entities participating in the M:N relationship.
  • Add foreign keys in the new relation referencing the primary keys of the entities they came from
  • Add any simple attributes of the M:N relationship as attributes in the new relation

C.content:
• Create a new relation containing a primary key made from the name of the relation
  • Add any simple attributes of the M:N relationship as attributes in the new relation.
  • If one of the parent attributes has total participation, add its primary key to the new relation
  • Add foreign keys referencing the primary key of the entities they came from

D.content:
• Create a new relation
  • Include a composite primary key with the name of the M:N relationship, and the primary key of the entity with the most attributes.
  • Add a foreign key in the new relation referencing the primary key of the entity
  • Add any simple attributes of the M:N relationship to the new relation

question.content:
We have a relationship R(A,B,C,D,E).

Given two Functional Dependencies: {A} ---> {B} and {B,C} ---> {D,E}, which one of the following statements can be inferred:

explanation.content:
Option A - Given A we know what B is from the first Function Dependency but to determine E we would need C for the second Function Dependency.

Option B - This is the correct answer as given A we know what B is from the first Function Dependency. We now know both B and C so we also know D and E from the second Functional Dependency. Therefore from A and C we can determine E.

Option C - From the second functional dependency to determine D and E we need both B and C, however we can't determine C through this option.

Option D - BC is not a candidate key as we are unable to determine what A is through this combination

Option E - This option is incorrect as only option B is correct.

D.content: BC is a candidate key

question.content: What is the name of this notation?

explanation.content: This is a Multivalued Attribute (double lined oval) which can have more than one value at a time for an attribute, hence the double lines symbolising that.

C.content: Composite Attribute

D.content: Multivalued Attribute

question.content:
Given the relation
R [A, B, C]
and the following set of functional dependencies
F = { A → B
B → C }

What is the Normal Form for R

explanation.content: The key for R is A, and C is transitively dependent on A. Hence R fails the 3NF test. There are no partial dependencies in R. Hence R passes the 2NF test.

C.content: BCNF

D.content: All of the above

question.content:
What am I?

- I live in the Entity Relationship Model

- I'm in a relationship with myself

- I like to play two different roles in this relationship

explanation.content:
From the question we are given:

- That it is something on the ER model.

- It has a relationship therefore we assume that we are talking about an entity.

- The entity has a relationship with itself and plays two roles in this relationship then the relationship we are talking about is a recursive relationship.

 

Therefore the answer is an entity in a recursive relationship.

A.content: An entity in a relationship with a weak entity

C.content: An entity with an disjoint subclass

D.content: An entity with an overlapping subclass

question.content: The schema of a database is

explanation.content: Schema is the result of database design, which could include conceptual modelling (for example through ER diagrams), mapping of ER to relational model, and normalisation

A.content: Created through update operations in the database

C.content: Determined during database design

D.content: Expected to change frequently

question.content: Which of the following is not the type of null values in Entity-Relationship?

explanation.content: This is problem is based on the slide of Module 3, page 15.

C.content: Unknown

D.content: Missing

question.content:
Two Chess players (One player playing with the white pieces (WP) and another playing with the black pieces (BP)) play a game of chess. The result is recorded and their ratings are then recalculated based on the result.

 

What is the Candidate Key/s and the highest normal form for these relationships?

explanation.content:
The only possible candidate key is WP Player ID and BP Player ID. 

This is in 2NF as WP Player new rating and BP Player new rating are functionally dependent on Result.

A.content:
Candidate Key is Result.

This is in 1NF.

B.content:
Candidate Key is Result and WP Player ID.
This is in 2NF.

C.content:
Candidate Key is WP Player ID and BP Player ID.
This is in 2NF.

D.content:
Candidate Key is WP Player ID and BP Player ID.
This is in BCNF.

question.content: Which is the equivalent method to represent the following relationship

explanation.content:
Every Course must be offered by a Department (Student Min = 1)

Each Couse must only be offered by one Department (Student Max = 1)

Not every Department has Courses (Department Min = 0)

Each Department can have many Courses (Department Max = n)

question.content: In phpmyadmin, should you use foreign keys if all the data is easily accessible anyway?

explanation.content: You need to ensure that only values that appear in the database are permitted. e.g. You have a CUSTOMER table and an ORDERS table. All orders must be associated with a customer, and customers have a unique ID (primary key) in the CUSTOMER table. By associating orders in the ORDER table with the foreign key customer unique ID in the CUSTOMER table, you ensure all orders have a customer.

B.content: No - the data is all there ready to be used. No need to link tables and complicate the database.

C.content: No - it is simpler to use more primary keys, even if they are the same in two different tables.

D.content: Yes - as it is a more complex topic, it shows you have a strong grasp on phpmyadmin.

question.content: What is the Foreign key?

explanation.content:
Foreign key in a table represents one or more attributes that reference the primary key attributes of another table.

The Foreign is defined in a second table, but it refers to the primary key or a unique key in the first table.

A.content: It is a key in a relational database that is unique for each record.

B.content: It is a field in one table that uniquely identifies a row of another table or the same table.

C.content: Represent the various properties of the entity the table represents

D.content: A set of attributes within a table whose values can be used to uniquely identify a tuple.

question.content: During which phase of the software development life cycle is a data flow diagram (DFD) usually created?

explanation.content:
The data flow diagram is suited to the analysis task as it provides a high-level view of the information system and does not concern itself with design details. A DFD also does not make assumptions about the systems speed, cost or time.  

 

See module 2 lecture notes.

C.content: The design phase.

D.content: The implementation phase.

question.content: What are the 4 main database integrity constraints ? ( as per lecture 6)

explanation.content:
The 4 main database integrity constraints are:

Domain constraint
Entity integrity constraint
Referential integrity constraint
Key constraint

A.content: Domain Constraints, Entity Integrity constraints, Size constraints, Tuple constraints.

B.content: Tuple constraints, entity integrity constraints, referential constraints, key constraints.

C.content: Size constraints, entity constraints, key constraints, domain constraints

D.content: Domain constraints, entity integrity constraints, referential constraints, key constraints.

question.content:
When you want to set a foreign key on an existing table using phpMyAdmin

 

For example, create foreign key salaries.emp_no that reference employees.emp_no

 

employees [emp_no, DOB, first_name, last_name, gender, hire_date]

salaries [salary_id, from_date, to_date, salary, emp_no]

 

What should you do first?

explanation.content:
The correct answer is B:

The column must be indexed before being set as a foreign key

Answer A: The emp_no is a primary key, so it is already indexed

Answer C: The salary_id is a primary key, so it is already indexed

C.content: Create an index for salaries.salary_id

D.content: None of them

question.content:
Solve the following SQL problem:

 

Find the total number of employees who earn more than 40000, in
departments with more than 5 employees.

 

SELECT D_No, Count(*)
FROM EMPLOYEE

PART TO BE IMPLEMENTED

explanation.content:
A  is the correct answer.   It first select department with at least 5 employees with the sub query, then use 'AND' to intersect those result with the salary with salary bigger than 40000 

B will return :The query will return departments with more than 5 employees earning 40000,

C is wrong because it first choose the table with at least 5 employee and then Salary bigger than 40000 which is totally wrong.

D is wrong because it is COUNT the table with more than 5 department it is not select 5 department more than 5 employees, and the DEPARTMENT table is not needed to use here and at the that table is not stated at the FROM ... line

E is wrong because Department number is not select at the main query, it can not be sub query with the line after HAVING .... line, and the logic is totally wrong.

A.content:
WHERE salary >40000 and D_No IN

(SELECT D_No
FROM EMPLOYEE
GROUP BY D_No
HAVING count(*) >5)

GROUP BY D_No;

C.content:
WHERE COUNT(*) >5 

AND Salary > 40000 ;

D.content:
WHERE salary >40000 and D_No IN
(SELECT D_No
FROM EMPLOYEE
GROUP BY D_No
HAVING Count(D_no)>5

WHERE D_no = DEPARTMENT.Dnumber)

GROUP BY D_No;

question.content: To include integrity constraint in a existing relation use :

explanation.content: Explanation:SYNTAX – alter table table-name add constraint , where constraint can be any constraint on the relation.

C.content: Alter table

D.content: Drop table

question.content:
Determine the candidate key(s) for the following relation

R[A,B,C,D,E,F]

A---->C

B---->E,F

F---->A,D

explanation.content:
B->E,F (B,E,F)

F->A,D(B,E,F,D,A)

A->C(A,B,C,D,E,F)

D.content: AB

question.content:
consider the table JERRYS_GF [jerry_id, new_gf_id, home_planet, method_of_celebration]

 

Which query would select the new_gf_id and home_planet from the above table, where jerrys new girlfriend likes to celebrate "with a hunt"

explanation.content:
A: is correct

B is incorrect due to the AND in the select section

C: is incorrect as it does not select new_gf_id

D is incorrect as it selects tuples of girlfriends who like to celebrate without a hunt

A.content:
SELECT new_gf_id, home_planet FROM JERRYS_GF

WHERE method_of_celebration = 'with a hunt'

B.content:
SELECT new_gf_id AND home_planet FROM JERRYS_GF
WHERE method_of_celebration = 'with a hunt'

C.content:
SELECT jerry_id, home_planet FROM JERRYS_GF
WHERE method_of_celebration = 'with a hunt'

D.content:
SELECT new_gf_id, home_planet FROM JERRYS_GF
WHERE method_of_celebration = 'not with a hunt'

question.content:
Consider the following relational schemes for a library database: Book (Title, Author, Catalog_no, Publisher, Year, Price) Collection (Title, Author, Catalog_no) with in the following functional dependencies:

 

I. Title Author --> Catalog_no
II. Catalog_no --> Title, Author, Publisher, Year
III. Publisher Title Year --> Price


Assume {Author, Title} is the key for both schemes. Which of the following statements is true?

explanation.content:
Book (Title, Author, Catalog_no, Publisher, Year, Price)
Collection (Title, Author, Catalog_no)


with in the following functional dependencies:


I. Title, Author --> Catalog_no
II. Catalog_no --> Title, Author, Publisher, Year
III. Publisher, Title, Year --> Price

 

Assume {Author, Title} is the key for both schemes
The table "Collection" is in BCNF as there is only one functional dependency “Title Author –> Catalog_no” and {Author, Title} is key for collection.
Book is not in BCNF because Catalog_no is not a key and there is a functional dependency “Catalog_no –> Title Author Publisher Year”.
Book is not in 3NF because non-prime attributes (Publisher Year) are transitively dependent on key [Title, Author].
Book is in 2NF because every non-prime attribute of the table is either dependent on the whole of a candidate key [Title, Author], or on another non prime attribute. In table book, candidate keys are {Title, Author} and {Catalog_no}. In table Book, non-prime attributes (attributes that do not occur in any candidate key) are Publisher, Year and Prince

A.content: Both Book and Collection are in BCNF.

B.content: Both Book and Collection are in 3NF only.

C.content: Book is in2NF and Collection is in 3NF.

D.content: Both Book and Collection are in 2NF only.

question.content:
Which is the SQL that be able to create an updatable view?
Note that all tables below are updatable.

explanation.content:
Updatable View is a view that can insert, update and delete row.
In order to be an updateble view, the following several conditions are needed.

 

　　summary functions (AVG、COUNT、SUM、MIN、MAX etc) are not included.
　　GROUP BY、HAVING、MODEL、CONNECT BY,START WITH,DISTINCT are not included.
　　collection formula in the list of SELECT syntax
　　sub query in the list of SELECT syntax
　　sub query to be designated WITH READ ONLY
　　no join more than 1 table (there is an exception)

A.content:
CREATE VIEW HI-PRICE-PRODUCT (ProductID, Name)
AS SELECT ProductID, Name FROM PRODUCT WHERE Unitcost > 1000

B.content:
CREATE VIEW ORDED-PRODUCT (ProductID)
AS SELECT DISTINCT ProductID, FROM ORDER

C.content:
CREATE VIEW PRODUCT-ORDER (ProductID, Amount)
AS SELECT ProductID, Sum(Amount) FROM ORDER GROPU BY ProductID

D.content:
CREATE VIEW AVERAGE-AMOUNTE-ORDER (AverageOrderAmount)
AS SELECT AVG(Orderamount) FROM ORDER

question.content:
Create table Manager(ID numeric,Name varchar(20),budget numeric,Details varchar(30));
Inorder to ensure that the value of budget is non-negative which of the following should be used?
